awd_titl_txt: Accelerating Open and FAIR Data Practices Across the Earth, Space, and Environmental Sciences: A Pilot with the NSF to Support Public Access to Research Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This project implements FAIR data practices across the Earth, space, and environmental sciences. By the end of the project, data citations for data funded by NSF EAR grants are captured in the NSF Public Access Repository (NSF PAR) and knowledge of leading practices and workflows around data citation are well known across the AGU community.  This project, funded as a pilot activity for the NSF PAR system, will have the outcome of strengthening the ecosystem for data in support of publications. 
 
AGU will work with its publishing partner Wiley to ensure that data citations are tracked and exposed in articles.  CHORUS will develop technical connections with Scholix to obtain data citation information to augment its publication information that it makes available to NSF.   AGU will join Dryad as a member and use the Dryad repository as a location for data deposit when a discipline specific repository is unavailable.  Outreach activities targeting awareness and adoption will be organized through AGU and ESIP’s Data FAIR workshops at scientific meetings, journal society meetings, and repository community meetings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
AGU made a transformational impact across Earth and space science journals, instilling expectations among authors that the data and software supporting their research findings must be deposited into a trusted, community-accepted repository, described in the availability statement of the paper, and cited in the References Section. The statement “data available upon request” is not acceptable. AGU’s systematic approach to ensuring that all published papers, especially those funded by the National Science Foundation’s EAR division, have proper data and software citations had the following measurable impacts: 

  1. For AGU authors: Provide clear guidance with examples of what is expected for data and software citation in a scholarly publication (https://www.agu.org/publications/authors/journals/data-software-for-authors; https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.5124741) Access to experts to ask questions through our datahelp@agu.org email. From March 2021 to January 2024, the datahelp@agu.org email has answered over 900 questions from authors, editors, and researchers on sharing data and software.

  2. For AGU journal staff, editors and reviewers: checklists for availability statements and citations (https://data.agu.org/resources/availability-citation-checklist-for-authors) along with guidance on acceptable flexibility and access to the datahelp@agu.org email to get questions answered. 

  3. For machine actionability of data and software citations for all journals and disciplines: the discovery of mis-aligned workflows, legacy code, and xml configurations that resulted in deleted data and software citation DOIs and incorrect parsing of mis-identified citations. This discovery work was conducted both with AGU’s publishing partner Wiley as well as a large group of like-minded publishers and publishing infrastructure experts. This same community documented the best practices for all journal production workflows to ensure proper machine actionability, ensuring data and software citations are linked to their corresponding publications. Publication: Journal Production Guidance for Software and Data Citations, https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-023-02491-7 

  4. For CHORUS reporting: Through this grant, CHORUS piloted tracing data citations in their funder and publisher reports. As of this report they have implemented this capability across their entire reporting capability. The work described in #3 above was instrumental in providing that machine-actionable content for this to be possible. 

  5. For the AGU/ESIP Data Help Desk: Educational materials, demos, and short talks were provided at all of the Data Help Desk events throughout this grant. At these same meetings, workshops and short courses provided more detailed information about data and software documentation and citation ensuring transparency and attribution. Data and software citation materials were provided and applicable for all Earth, space, and environmental disciplines and journals. 

Remarkable improvement in human-readable and machine-actionable data and software citations 

Today, over 80% of AGU’s published papers reference supporting data and/or software. Of those citations, ~60% are properly formatted data or software citations with corresponding DOIs, allowing them to be machine actionable and ensuring credit for data and software outputs can be tracked. In contrast, at the start of the project, none of AGU’s published papers contained machine-actionable data and software citations. Twenty percent had human-readable citations, but those were not supported with machine-actionable formats. 

This work has established the leading practices for authors, journal staff, editors, and reviewers for scientific paper availability statements and citations for data and software making research findings more transparent, journal production systems better aligned with the requirements of data and software citations, and creators of data and software receive the attribution that honors our Earth, space, and environmental data as a “world heritage”, as stated in AGU’s Data Position Statement. 

An AGU Editors Vox describing the scope of the journal pilot that resulted in significant improvement of cited data and software is scheduled for publication in early 2025.
